column4: hi... anyone know how to check the version of a pci slot from within linux?
could 'lspci' do it?
I tried that and another one dmidecode... no luck
or I couldn't interpret the reulsts....
what do you mean by version?

apparently there are different versions of PCI like version 1 and 2 and 2.2.,.. I'm not sure on the specs, but I have a digium/asterisk card and it needs 2.2. The card doesn't show up in the lspci listing yet the kernel requirements are like 2.2 or 2.4 so no worries there!
so while I have found the specs for my motherboard are sifficient in a doc online, I want to see what the OS thinks
juluisspencer:  ah I follow now...have you had a look in your kernel to see if version 2 of pci and that is enabled?
I'm not sure... I'm using a standard distro kernel... uh... I have ubuntu on my laptop, but not on this particulr computer
perhaps it's not just in there...will have a look and see if i can find where it would be
it should make no diff though...
yeah... seems odd though as PCI v 2.2 is retty old.
like 2004 or before
I mean... it probably came out around 2003 I'm guessing atthe latest
so talking start of 2.6 kernel
just look around with make menuconfig and see if all the pci stuff is enabled :)
yeah... always found that really clunky...
kow if there's a search other than looking in the actual file?
it's the only thing i've ever used
thanks for the tip all the same.
does cat /proc/pci bring anything up?
no
(I think)
I think I tried that
